title: Toxic Megacolon in Ulcerative Colitis
setup_script: A 32-year-old woman with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with severe abdominal pain, distension, fever, and bloody diarrhea. X-ray shows colonic diameter of 7 cm; she is hypotensive and tachycardic.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Recognize signs of toxic megacolon: severe colitis, systemic toxicity, colonic dilatation >6 cm.
Resuscitate with IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and bowel rest; monitor electrolytes and hemodynamics.
Order labs including CBC, CMP, CRP, stool cultures; arrange abdominal X-ray and CT to confirm extent and rule out perforation.
Consult gastroenterology; start high-dose IV steroids and consider infliximab or cyclosporine if steroid refractory.
Place nasogastric tube for decompression; position patient to minimize colonic distension; avoid opiates and antidiarrheals.
Monitor vital signs and abdominal exam closely; repeat abdominal imaging every 6-12 h.
Identify signs of failure of medical management (continued distension, perforation, sepsis) requiring surgery.
Discuss surgical options: subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy versus total proctocolectomy; plan subtotal colectomy emergently.
Obtain informed consent; explain risk of bleeding, infection, and need for future restorative surgery (J-pouch).
Perform subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy; leave rectal stump for future completion.
Postoperative management: monitor hemodynamics, fluid balance, stoma function; continue steroids and taper gradually.
Plan long-term management including staged proctectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis and gastroenterology follow-up.

critical_decision_points: Early recognition of toxic megacolon and initiation of aggressive medical therapy.
Monitoring for failure of medical therapy and timely decision for surgical intervention.
Performing subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy in unstable patient.
Postoperative care with fluid management and steroid taper.
Planning for staged restorative surgery and coordinating with gastroenterology.
